Chapter 7 Other analyses In this chapter, I quickly investigated effects of functional traits and weather on individual growth. 7.1 Methods I used linear model for individual growth potential relation to functional traits at the individual or species level. For each dataset, I first used a step procedure to select explanatory variables before using linear models with multiple variables. I then plotted the individual relations between response and explanatory variables. 7.2 Results 7.2.1 Bridge As highlighted by Hérault et al. (2011), wood specific gravity is a strong driver of species growth potential (\(\beta=-1.98, p<0.001, R^2=0.563\)), with dense tree growing logically slower.   log(gmax) Predictors Estimates CI p (Intercept) -1.26 -1.66 – -0.85 <0.001 wsg [log] -1.98 -2.76 – -1.20 <0.001 Observations 22 R2 / R2 adjusted 0.584 / 0.563 7.2.2 ParacouITV Interestingly, leaf dry matter content seems to drive individual growth potential within species of Symphonia and Eschweilera genera (\(\beta=-0.91, p=0.016, R^2=0.083\)), but the signal is weak.   log(gmax) Predictors Estimates CI p (Intercept) -1.48 -3.19 – 0.24 0.090 CC 0.01 -0.00 – 0.02 0.082 LA [log] -0.14 -0.36 – 0.08 0.221 LDMC [log] -0.91 -1.65 – -0.17 0.016 Observations 124 R2 / R2 adjusted 0.105 / 0.083 7.2.3 hydroParacou Interestingly, turgor loss point and stomatal density appear to influence species growth potential with a positive effect (\(\beta=1.13, p=0.004\) & \(\beta=0.28, p<0.001\), \(R^2=0.0312\)).
